head.title: Only in, and From, New York

hedline.hl1: Only in, and From, New York

abstract.p: Howard Goldberg column on wines available at Vintage New York, which opened in Manhattan's SoHo in July; photo (M)

block.p: Labor Day, rewarding the fruits of labor and laborers, is tailor-made for the grape and for wine producers. Once a year, a swig of chauvinism (emphasizing the syllable ''vin'') is in order. This brings us to Vintage New York, a spiffy wine shop that opened in July.
The shop, at 482 Broome Street (Wooster Street) in SoHo, carries nearly 150 wines, only from New York regions: Long Island, the Finger Lakes, Hudson Valley and Lake Erie-Chautauqua.

Labor Day, rewarding the fruits of labor and laborers, is tailor-made for the grape and for wine producers. Once a year, a swig of chauvinism (emphasizing the syllable ''vin'') is in order. This brings us to Vintage New York, a spiffy wine shop that opened in July.
The shop, at 482 Broome Street (Wooster Street) in SoHo, carries nearly 150 wines, only from New York regions: Long Island, the Finger Lakes, Hudson Valley and Lake Erie-Chautauqua.
Because the place is an extension of a farm winery, the Rivendell Winery in New Paltz in the Hudson Valley, state law lets it be open Sundays.
Since the owners, Robert Ransom and Susan Wine, let you taste any wines ($5 for five one-ounce tastings, refundable with a $50 purchase), choosing bottles is painless.
To celebrate a holiday treated as summer's formal end, try the bracing Macari nonvintage brut sparkling wine ($18) from the North Fork of Long Island.

Vintage New York offers such nifty aperitif and food-oriented buys as the '98 Seyval blanc ($13) from Clinton Vineyards in the Hudson Valley, pioneers in this hybrid; Standing Stone's '98 Vidal blanc ($10), a hybrid from the Finger Lakes; Duck Walk's '98 pinot grigio ($15), South Fork of Long Island; and Schneider's '98 Potato Barn White ($14), North Fork.

For hamburgers, try Anthony Road's nonvintage Vintner's Red ($9), Finger Lakes, and Libertyville Cellars Bistro Red ($8, Rivendell's second label), Hudson Valley. Fancy meat deserves '97 Paumanok merlot ($18, North Fork) and '97 Gristina merlot ($18, North Fork).

Among lightly sweet whites, Wagner's '99 Melody ($7, Finger Lakes) and Lakewood's '98 vignoles ($8, Finger Lakes) are winners. For a nosh, check Baldwin Vineyards's nonvintage strawberry wine ($10, Hudson Valley).
